fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • In a comment piece about the changing fortunes of Roy Hodgson as manager of Liverpool FC, we were wrong to say that Blackburn Rovers was the only football club that ever sacked him (Roy of the ragers, 25 October, page 31). • Greece's finance minister should have been named as George Papaconstantinou instead of Michalis, which is the forename of his late uncle and one-time foreign minister (Greek bonds hit by election speculation and political unrest, 28 October, page 33). • A piece about an expanding network of gold-bullion vending machines reported that the machines' owner, Thomas Geissler, had said in an interview that he was due to meet representatives of Harrods to discuss siting of a UK machine. The London department store asks us to make clear it has no plans for such a meeting. A representative of Mr Geissler has clarified the latter's intention was to indicate the type of location his company is focusing on for its machines (In era of financial anxiety, bullion vending machines strike gold, 22 October, page 28). • An interview with cyclist Victoria Pendleton read: "At first, while training for the keirin, she reaches 75mph as her front wheel remains a nerveless few millimetres behind the back tyre of a motorbike." That ought to have been 75kph (Dreaming of being chased by killer monsters is normal for me, 26 October, page 6, Sport). • A story should have sited a bottle-throwing incident involving the band Mumford & Sons at the annual Electric Picnic festival in County Laois, Ireland, not at a putative Electric Proms in Dublin as we had it (Pass notes No 2,868, 25 October, page 3, G2).
